items.item_details:
Hi Ms. Williams,
	 
	My name is Tina Le and I was the student Mr. Romero introduced to you last week. I just wanted to email you additional information about the Academy and the NROTC scholarship.
	 
	Last month, I was awarded the 4- Year Navy ROTC scholarship. I may use this scholarship on any of the five universities I've selected (UMich, BU, SDSU, Georgia Tech, and Virginia U) but must train with the military unit on campus. In addition to receiving my B.S. at the end of four years, I will also be commissioned as an officer (Ensign) in the U.S. Navy and will serve for a minimum of 5 years.
	 
	The academy is a bit different in that gaining an acceptance immediately gives me a full ride scholarship. I was invited for an all-expense paid Candidate Visitation Weekend in July (the actual visit was two weeks ago). On the first night there, I was given a "Letter of Assurance" by the Dean. This LOA ensures my acceptance so long as I fulfill the last requirement on the checklist (nomination from the Congressman/Senator). Less than 200 LOAs are given out per year (out of a class of 1200 students) and by receiving one, I am almost guaranteed a nomination. Similar to NROTC, I will also be commissioned as an Ensign and must serve a minimum of 5 years after college. 
	 
	Thanks for your time!
	 
	Best,
	Tina Le

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Follow Up to Board Study Session of November 13, 2014:  
Budget Update
	 
	 
At the Board Study Session of November 13, 2014, agenda item 5.02 provided a discussion and update on the district’s current budget.  There was an overview of district wide budget assumptions, highlight of the 2014/15 adopted budget, definition of categories of funds, review of ESUHSD funds, estimate of available funds for total compensation and services, the cost of a 1% increase on salary and the cost to reduce class size by one student.
	 
The district has signed a Tentative Agreement (TA) with the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), and, through the Meet and Confer process, the District has agreed to a salary increase with the Administrator Collaborative of East Side (ACES) pending Board ratification. Both of these Agreements are identical regarding salary compensation and are not above what has been offered to the other bargaining units.
	 
We have had seven (5/2, 8, 19, 6/3 canceled by ESTA, 9/16, 28, 10/13, 29) bargaining sessions with the East Side Teachers Association (ESTA).  Our next session is scheduled for December 2, 2014.
	 
We have had five (5/22, 6/28, 9/24, 30, 10/14) bargaining sessions with the California School Employees Association (CSEA).  Our next session is scheduled for December 1, 2014.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:15 p.m. regarding Proposed Amended Board Policy #3290, including Internal Controls to protect the Integrity of the Public Funds and to Ensure that Funds raised benefit Public Education, and that the Contracts are entered into on a Competitive Basis Pursuant to Procedures contained in Section 20111 of the Public Contract Code or through the Issuance of a Request for Proposal (Education Code Section 35182.5)
	 
Administration is proposing amended Board Policy 3290, including a new proposed section (“Corporate Sponsorship”) which would allow the Board to enter into agreements or arrangements with an outside entities for the sponsorship of an educational, athletic, or other District programs or activities and, when appropriate, such agreements or arrangements may allow the outside entity to advertise or promote its business, product, or service in District publications or on District property or web sites.  A copy of the draft amended Board Policy #3290 is attached.
	 
Pursuant to Education Code section 35182.5, the Board may not enter into or renew a contract or permit a school within the district to enter into or renew a contract that grants exclusive or nonexclusive advertising within the district to a person, business, or corporation, unless the Board first adopts a policy after a public hearing of the Board to ensure that the school district has internal controls in place to protect the integrity of the public funds and to ensure that funds raised benefit public education, and that the contracts are entered into on a competitive basis pursuant to procedures contained in Section 20111 of the Public Contract Code or through the issuance of a Request for Proposal.
	 
Draft amended Board Policy #3290, attached hereto incorporates the same internal controls outlined in Board Policy #3312 (relating to contracts for the exclusive or nonexclusive sale of carbonated beverages or nonnutritious beverages or nonnutritious food, which are also governed by Education Code section 35182.5), and would also require that any such corporate sponsorship which grant exclusive or nonexclusive advertising rights contracts are entered into on a competitive basis pursuant to procedures contained in Section 20111 of the Public Contract Code or through the issuance of a Request for Proposal.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board hold a public hearing regarding proposed amended Board Policy #3290, including proposed internal controls to protect the integrity of the public funds and to ensure that funds raised benefit public education, and that the contracts are entered into on a competitive basis pursuant to procedures contained in Section 20111 of the Public Contract Code or through the issuance of a request for proposal.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
J. Manuel Herrera, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Pending Board Vacancy: Process for Appointment and Provisional Appointment to the Governing Board
	 
	 
Board Member Carrasco’s election to the San Jose City Council will result in a vacancy on the Governing Board for the remainder of Member Carrasco’s term.
	 
Board Bylaw 9223 (a copy of which is attached) specifies the process for provisional appointments to the Governing Board. Per Board Bylaw 9223, when a vacancy occurs four or more months before the end of a Board member's term, the Board shall, within 60 days of the date of the vacancy or the filing of the member's deferred resignation, either order an election or make a provisional appointment. If no election is ordered, then the Board will make a provisional appointment.
	 
Board Bylaw 9223 specifies that the Board shall advertise in the local media to solicit “candidate applications or nominations.” Thus, the Board must decide whether it will seek applications or nominations for the upcoming Board vacancy. Per Board Bylaw 9223, the Board must also establish the timeline and the rules for the selection of the provisional appointees, and approve an application and a set of questions for all candidates to answer in writing. The Board must also appoint an ad hoc committee consisting of less than a quorum of the Board to ensure that applicants are eligible for Board membership as required by law. The applications of all eligible candidates will be forwarded to all Board members. The Board may appoint an advisory committee to, at a public meeting, review applications, interview candidates and make recommendations to the Board. The Board is not restricted by the advisory committee’s recommendation and may appoint any of the eligible applicants. The Board shall interview the candidates, of it’s choosing from the list of eligible applicants, at a public meeting, accept oral or written public input, and select the provisional appointee by a majority vote.
		 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
As stipulated by the Board of Trustees.
items.item_recommendation: As stipulated by the Board of Trustees.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item: 11.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Frank Biehl, Board Member
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Call for Nominations to CSBA Delegate Assembly
		 
		 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for the CSBA Delegate Assembly.  Any CSBA member board is eligible to nominate board members within their geographical region or subregion.  Boards may nominate as many individuals as it chooses by submitting a nomination form for each nominee.  All nominees must serve on CSBA member boards and give their approval prior to being nominated to CSBA's Delegate Assembly.
		 
All nominees must submit a one-page, single-sided, candidate biographical sketch form.  An optional one-page, one-sided resume (resume cannot be substituted for the candidate biographical sketch form).  All nominations must be postmarked by the United States Postal Office no later than Tuesday, January 7, 2015.  Faxes are also acceptable, but must be received by January 7, 2015.  It is the nominee’s responsibility to confirm that all nomination materials have been received by the CSBA Leadership Services department by this due date. Late submissions will not be accepted.
		 
Elected Delegates will serve a two-year term, beginning April 1, 2015, through March 31, 2017.  There are two required Delegate Assembly meetings each year, one on May 16-17, 2015, in Sacramento and one on December 2-3, 2015, preceding the CSBA Annual Education Conference and Trade Show in San Diego.
		 
		 
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Expenses to attend required meetings
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees consider submitting nomination(s) to the CSBA Delegate Assembly.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Receive and Adopt Third Reading of Amended Board ByLaw #9270 Conflict of Interest and Revolving Door Restrictions and Reauthorize Resolution #2014/2015-06
	 
	 
The Government Code and the Rules and Regulations adopted by the Fair Political Practices Commission require the District to designate positions which are required to submit disclosures of financial interests, and to update the titles of positions when new positions are created, when position titles are changed, or when positions or position duties are revised or modified to fall within the disclosure categories.  The District is required to submit the proposed approved changes to the Santa Clara County Counsel.
	 
Amended Board ByLaw 9270 and Resolution #2014/2015-06 (adopting the Conflict of Interest Code) were approved and adopted by the Board at the October 16, 2014, Regular Board meeting.  Since that approval, County Counsel’s Office has notified the District and Counsel of some additional requested changes and additions and corrections.  The attached revised Board ByLaw includes and reflects such requested changes and additions and corrections.  
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive and adopt the third reading of amended Board ByLaw 9270 as presented, and reauthorize Resolution #2014/2015-06 adopting the Conflict of Interest Code.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve One Day Material Decrease of School Attendance for Santa Teresa High School due to School Threats and Rumors of Shooting and Bombing on October 9, 2014
	 
	 
The California Department of Education Form J-13A, Request for Allowance of Attendance because of Emergency Conditions, is being submitted for Board review and approval. The District is requesting substitution of estimated day of attendance for actual day of attendance in accordance with the provisions of Education Code Section 46392.  Approval of this request will authorize use of the estimated day of attendance in the computation of apportionment for Santa Teresa High School for Thursday, October 9, 2014, during which school attendance was materially decreased because of threats and rumors of a shooting and bombing at the school site.
	 
The estimated average daily attendance (ADA) decrease on October 9, 2014, is expected to be 4.95, which is approximately $42,000.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Estimated $42,000 (4.95 ADA) 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve submission of Form J-13A for the one day material decrease of attendance on Thursday, October 9, 2014, for Santa Teresa High School.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Determine that Design-Build Delivery for the Yerba Buena High School New Student Union and Quad Modernization Project will Reduce Project Costs, Expedite the Project’s Completion, or Provide Features not Achievable through the Design-Bid-Build Process
	 
On February 13, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved the Yerba Buena High School New Student Union and Quad Modernization Project, to be funded by Measure E and Measure I Bond proceeds, and School Facilities funds. On February 14, 2013, the Board considered public works construction project delivery methods available for this project, including design-bid-build, design-build, energy service contracting, and lease lease-back.  
	 
For this project, District staff have examined possible construction delivery methods and have concluded that the use of design-build delivery for the project offers the following potential advantages to the District not available under a traditional design-bid-build delivery method:
	 
Simplified contracting and contract administration:  There is one contract with the design-build entity instead of separate contracts with an architect and a contractor.   This reduces administrative burden and associated costs.
Cost containment:  The design-build entity is under a contract to complete the project meeting the District’s stated requirements within the contract price.
Cost savings:  Innovative, cost-effective solutions meeting performance criteria can be achieved by collaboration between the designer and builder, adding construction practicality to design imagination.  The builder is involved in the design process from the beginning and can provide helpful insights on construction materials and methods that can make the design more efficient and less costly to construct, operate and maintain. 
Early cost definition:  Project costs are determined much sooner than with the traditional design-bid-build process. The design-build method enables the District to determine the cost of the project upon award of the design-build contract instead of after Division of the State Architect approval and construction contract bidding. This early cost knowledge allows the District to make informed decisions on detailed scope in order to ensure equity of outcomes among the school sites.
Reduced number of change orders and disputes:  Because the designer and builder are part of the same design-build entity and the District is not the guarantor of the completeness and accuracy of the work of the architect/engineer, the District may avoid conflicts and disputes and the corresponding costs of those conflicts and disputes that can arise between the architect/engineer and construction contractor.
Greater risk shifting and more efficient risk allocation:  The vesting of design and construction functions under one entity enables proper allocation of risk under the design-build contract, because the contractor’s involvement in constructability review and existing site condition surveys during preconstruction activities reduces or eliminates the need for redesign during the construction phase. 
Reduction in adversarial relationships:  The designer and builder are teamed together, working under a single contract.  This teaming can significantly reduce traditional conflicts and finger pointing between designer and contractor, and eliminate the need for the District to referee disputes.
Time savings:  The design-build entity is allowed the freedom to explore time-saving construction methods or systems, while meeting the District’s stated criteria.  Early coordination between the designer and builder can help prevent construction delays.   Additionally, by overlapping design and construction to some extent, design-build can deliver the project faster than the design-bid-build approach.  Any and all of these elements can accelerate delivery of the new Student Union and modernized Quad.
Alternative selection process: Design-build entities may be selected on the basis of factors other than price alone.  Design-build entities can assemble a team of architects, engineers, subcontractors and suppliers with whom they have had previous successful collaborations, and that reflect the goals and needs of the project.  The District can select the winning team based on not only price, but also other factors, including technical expertise, life cycle cost over 15 years or more, skilled labor force availability, safety record, successful previous experience, project-specific plans and schedules, design, and other qualitative elements.
	 
Education Code §17250.20 stipulates that upon making a determination by the governing board that it is in the best interest of the District, the board may enter into a design-build contract for both the design and construction of a school facility if that expenditure exceeds two million five hundred thousand dollars ($2,500,000) if, after evaluation of the traditional design, bid, and build process of school construction and of the design-build process in a public meeting, the governing board makes written findings that use of the design-build process on the specific project under consideration will accomplish one of the following objectives:  reduce comparable project costs, expedite the project's completion, or provide features not achievable through the traditional design-bid-build method.  The governing board also shall review the guidelines developed pursuant to Education Code §17250.40 (Attachment A) and shall adopt a resolution approving the use of a design-build contract pursuant to this chapter prior to entering into a design-build contract.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees, having reviewed the guidelines developed pursuant to Education Code §17250.40, approve the determination that design-build delivery for the Yerba Buena High School New Student Union and Quad Modernization Project will reduce project costs, expedite the project’s completion, or provide features not achievable through the design-bid-build process.

Item:  17.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, and Nguyet Dinh, Administrator of Language Minority Programs
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Academic Criterion for Reclassification of English Learners to English Proficient Students
	 
	 
Consequent to the implementation of the Common Core State Standards and the California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress (CAASPP), Assembly Bill (AB) 484 suspended the California Standards Test (CST). Since CST can no longer be used as a criterion to reclassify English learners to English proficient students, the California Department of Education directed school districts to select another measure to replace the CST.
	 
For the 2014-15 school year, three of the four reclassification criteria remain unchanged:
Assessment of English language proficiency, using an objective assessment instrument, including but not limited to, the state test of English language development.
Teacher evaluation, including but not limited to, a review of the student’s curriculum mastery
Parent opinion and consultation
The fourth criterion requires a comparison of student performance on an objective assessment of basic skills in English-language arts. The assessments results must have an empirically established range of performance in basic skills based on the performance of English proficient students of the same age.
	 
School districts may identify assessments they will use to determine that English learners are meeting academic measures that indicate they are ready to reclassify. These assessment instruments need to measure basic skills for all students and produce results that show whether a student is performing at or close to grade level. Regulations also specify that local reclassification criteria must be reviewed by the school district committee on programs and services for English learners. 
	 
A District team convened to review English learners’ reclassification data, assessment instruments, and cut scores that can be used as the academic criterion for reclassification. The proposed criterion was reviewed and recommended by the District English Learner Advisory Committee (DELAC) at their October 2014 meeting.

 Overall proficiency level of 4 or 5, and at least a 3 in each

SUBJECT:
Receive Annual Developer Fees Report
	 
	 
Under Government Code Section 66006(b), each school district that imposes a developer fee must, after the close of each fiscal year, report to the public the beginning and ending balance for the fiscal year fees, interest, and other income to the developer fee fund, and expenditures incurred, including the amount of refund of developer fees pursuant to Government Code Section 66001(e).  
	 
Attached is a financial report of the activity for the 2013-14 fiscal year.
